botanical_details.potentially_harmful: All parts may cause severe discomfort if ingested, contact with the sap may irritate skin. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Iris may be rhizomatous or bulbous perennials, with narrow leaves and erect stems bearing flowers with 3 large spreading or pendent fall petals, alternating with 3 erect, often smaller, standard petals, in late winter, spring or early summer

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in well-drained, neutral to slightly acid loam in full sun or partial shade. Mulch in spring
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division from midsummer to early autumn, plant immediately in flowering positions
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove any dying foliage in autumn, old flower stems can be cut down after flowering. Tall varieties can have their leaf fans trimmed to one third of the total height to reduce wind rock while the plants are establishing
how_to_grow.pests: Slugs and snails may be a problem, sawflies can damage the leaves
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by aphid borne virus diseases, bacterial soft rot and grey moulds
